headline.main: ENGLISH LETTERS FROM AMERICA.; Correspondence of Mr. Russell with the London Times. AN EXCHANGE OF PRISONERS. POPUTAR MISTAKES AS TO FRANCE AND ENGLAND. POSSIBILITY OF A MILITARY DICTATORSHIP DIFFICULTIES OF RECONSTRUCTION. WHY THE INDEPENDENCE OF THE SOUTH IS INADMISSIBLE. THE EXPEDITION TO BEAUFORT. THE REMOVAL OF FREMONT. THE SRAUDS OF THE NEW-YORK HERALD. THE MISSION OF MESSRS. HUGHES AND WEED.

docs.lead_paragraph: The impression is forcing itself into a conviction that neither Gen. McCLELLAN nor any other General will convert the mass of men under arms about here into a well-disciplined army according to the European standard or the notions of the most easily satisfied military critics.

headline.main: OUR WAR CORRESPONDENCE.; AFFAIRS AT CAIRO. PROBABILITY OF A FORWARD MOVEMENT FORTIFYING AT COLUMBUS AND NEW-MADRID PREPARING WINTER QUARTERS FIRING AT FORTHOLT COTTON PROTECTED GUNBOATS WHATHAPPENS AT PADUCALL.

docs.lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding numberless newspaper reports to the contrary, it is evident no forward movement of importance will take place from here for a couple of weeks, at least. The Union commanders are not ready to commence successful offensive movements and of magnitude sufficient to gain, should they be successful, any really important result.

headline.main: NEWS OF THE DAY.; THE REBELLION.

docs.lead_paragraph: Important reconnoissances were yesterday made along our lines of the Potomac, to ascertain the positions and strength of the rebels. One, made in a balloon by Prof. LA MOUNTAIN, establishes the facts that the rebel force at Fairfax Courthouse is very light; that between that point and Vienna there is an increase of strength, and that all along the line very considerable additions have been made to the scouts of cavalry and infantry.

headline.main: Gen. Sherman's New Movements The Necessity for Procuring Comfortable Quartersfor the Troops Profits of the Sutlers, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: Col. NOBLE, of the Seventy-ninth New-York Highlanders, has resigned his position, and has been appointed by Gen. SHERMAN to collect all the cotton possible about here, picked and unpicked, ginned and unginned, and store, preparatory to a shipment of it to Col. TOMPKINS, of your City.

docs.snippet: My DEAR SIR: The mails for New-York by one of the transports closed to-day, and I write to inform you that I send no correspondence. I have been three days ashore, and my time has been mainly occupied in finding decent accommodations. Being easily...
docs.lead_paragraph: My DEAR SIR: The mails for New-York by one of the transports closed to-day, and I write to inform you that I send no correspondence. I have been three days ashore, and my time has been mainly occupied in finding decent accommodations. Being easily satisfied, I am happy to say that I am moderately comfortable.
